metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Machine Learning - Polynomial Regression
Polynomial Regression
If your data points clearly will not fit a linear regression (a straight line through all data points), it might be ideal for polynomial regression.
content.html: If your data points clearly will not fit a linear regression (a straight line through all data points), it might be ideal for polynomial regression.

content.text: Polynomial regression, like linear regression, uses the relationship between the variables x and y to find the best way to draw a line through the data points.
content.html: Polynomial regression, like linear regression, uses the relationship between the variables x and y to find the best way to draw a line through the data points.

content.text: How Does it Work?

Python has methods for finding a relationship between data-points and to draw a line of polynomial regression. We will show you how to use these methods instead of going through the mathematic formula.
content.html: Python has methods for finding a relationship between data-points and to draw a line of polynomial regression. We will show you how to use these methods instead of going through the mathematic formula.

content.text: In the example below, we have registered 18 cars as they were passing a certain tollbooth.
content.html: In the example below, we have registered 18 cars as they were passing a certain tollbooth.

content.text: We have registered the car's speed, and the time of day (hour) the passing occurred.
content.html: We have registered the car's speed, and the time of day (hour) the passing occurred.

content.text: The x-axis represents the hours of the day and the y-axis represents the speed:
content.html: The x-axis represents the hours of the day and the y-axis represents the speed:

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = [1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10,12,13,14,15,16,18,19,21,22]
y = [100,90,80,60,60,55,60,65,70,70,75,76,78,79,90,99,99,100]

plt.scatter(x, y)
plt.show()

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpyimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = [1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10,12,13,14,15,16,18,19,21,22]y = 
  [100,90,80,60,60,55,60,65,70,70,75,76,78,79,90,99,99,100]mymodel = 
  numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))myline = numpy.linspace(1, 22, 100)plt.scatter(x, y)plt.plot(myline, mymodel(myline))
  plt.show()

plt.show()

content.code_html:
import numpy
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = [1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10,12,13,14,15,16,18,19,21,22]
y = [100,90,80,60,60,55,60,65,70,70,75,76,78,79,90,99,99,100]

mymodel = numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))

myline = numpy.linspace(1, 22, 100)

plt.scatter(x, y)
plt.plot(myline, mymodel(myline))
plt.show()

  plt.show()

content.html: You can learn about the NumPy module in our NumPy Tutorial.

content.html: You can learn about the SciPy module in our SciPy Tutorial.

content.html: Display the diagram:

content.text: R-Squared
It is important to know how well the relationship between the values of the x- and y-axis is, if there are no relationship the polynomial regression can not be used to predict anything.
content.html: It is important to know how well the relationship between the values of the x- and y-axis is, if there are no relationship the polynomial regression can not be used to predict anything.

content.text: The relationship is measured with a value called the r-squared.
content.html: The relationship is measured with a value called the r-squared.

content.text: The r-squared value ranges from 0 to 1, where 0 means no relationship, and 1 means 100% related.
content.html: The r-squared value ranges from 0 to 1, where 0 means no relationship, and 1 means 100% related.

content.text: Python and the Sklearn module will compute this value for you, all you have to do is feed it with the x and y arrays:
content.html: Python and the Sklearn module will compute this value for you, all you have to do is feed it with the x and y arrays:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpyfrom sklearn.metrics import r2_scorex = 
  [1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10,12,13,14,15,16,18,19,21,22]y = 
  [100,90,80,60,60,55,60,65,70,70,75,76,78,79,90,99,99,100]mymodel = 
  numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))print(r2_score(y, mymodel(x)))

[1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10,12,13,14,15,16,18,19,21,22]y =
[100,90,80,60,60,55,60,65,70,70,75,76,78,79,90,99,99,100]mymodel =
numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))print(r2_score(y, mymodel(x)))

content.code_html:
import numpy
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score

x = [1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10,12,13,14,15,16,18,19,21,22]
y = [100,90,80,60,60,55,60,65,70,70,75,76,78,79,90,99,99,100]

mymodel = numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))

print(r2_score(y, mymodel(x)))

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import numpyfrom sklearn.metrics import r2_scorex = 
  [1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10,12,13,14,15,16,18,19,21,22]y = 
  [100,90,80,60,60,55,60,65,70,70,75,76,78,79,90,99,99,100]mymodel = 
  numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))print(r2_score(y, mymodel(x)))

content.text: Note: The result 0.94 shows that there is a very good relationship, and we can use polynomial regression in future predictions.
content.html: Note: The result 0.94 shows that there is a very good relationship, and we can use polynomial regression in future predictions.

content.text: Predict Future Values
Now we can use the information we have gathered to predict future values.
content.html: Now we can use the information we have gathered to predict future values.

content.text: Example: Let us try to predict the speed of a car that passes the tollbooth at around the time 17:00:
content.html: Example: Let us try to predict the speed of a car that passes the tollbooth at around the time 17:00:

content.text: To do so, we need the same mymodel array from the example above:
content.html: To do so, we need the same mymodel array from the example above:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpyfrom sklearn.metrics import r2_scorex = 
  [1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10,12,13,14,15,16,18,19,21,22]y = 
  [100,90,80,60,60,55,60,65,70,70,75,76,78,79,90,99,99,100]mymodel = 
  numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))speed = mymodel(17)print(speed)

content.text: The example predicted a speed to be 88.87, which we also could read from the diagram:
content.html: The example predicted a speed to be 88.87, which we also could read from the diagram:

content.text: Bad Fit?
Let us create an example where polynomial regression would not be the best method to predict future values.
content.html: Let us create an example where polynomial regression would not be the best method to predict future values.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpyimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = 
  [89,43,36,36,95,10,66,34,38,20,26,29,48,64,6,5,36,66,72,40]y = 
  [21,46,3,35,67,95,53,72,58,10,26,34,90,33,38,20,56,2,47,15]mymodel = 
  numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))myline = numpy.linspace(2, 95, 100)
  plt.scatter(x, y)plt.plot(myline, mymodel(myline))plt.show()

import numpy
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = [89,43,36,36,95,10,66,34,38,20,26,29,48,64,6,5,36,66,72,40]
y = [21,46,3,35,67,95,53,72,58,10,26,34,90,33,38,20,56,2,47,15]

mymodel = numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))

plt.plot(myline, mymodel(myline))

import numpyimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = 
  [89,43,36,36,95,10,66,34,38,20,26,29,48,64,6,5,36,66,72,40]y = 
  [21,46,3,35,67,95,53,72,58,10,26,34,90,33,38,20,56,2,47,15]mymodel =

content.text: And the r-squared value?
content.html: And the r-squared value?

content.code_html:
import numpy
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score

x = [89,43,36,36,95,10,66,34,38,20,26,29,48,64,6,5,36,66,72,40]
y = [21,46,3,35,67,95,53,72,58,10,26,34,90,33,38,20,56,2,47,15]

mymodel = numpy.poly1d(numpy.polyfit(x, y, 3))

print(r2_score(y, mymodel(x)))

content.text: The result: 0.00995 indicates a very bad relationship, and tells us that this data set is not suitable for polynomial regression.
content.html: The result: 0.00995 indicates a very bad relationship, and tells us that this data set is not suitable for polynomial regression.
